contenido.en:
Sometimes people mention Charles Taze Russell, one of the early promoters of our Bible work, as if he were the center of our faith. They say he made mistakes or had imperfect ideas. But does that really matter today? Is our faith based on a man... or on Godâ€™s Word?

ğŸ”¹ 1. We follow Christ, not men:
True Christians donâ€™t follow human leaders, but the Son of God. Jesus made it clear: â€œYou have one Teacher, and you are all brothersâ€ (Matthew 23:8). We didnâ€™t become Jehovahâ€™s Witnesses because of Russell, Rutherford, or any other man, but because of what we learned from the Bible. We are Jehovahâ€™s Witnesses because we see that this organization strives to teach the truth, act humbly, and do Godâ€™s will (Isaiah 43:10).

ğŸ”¹ 2. The Bible shows that even faithful servants make mistakes:
Peter denied Jesus three times but was later forgiven and used as a leader (Luke 22:61-62). The disciples thought Jesus would immediately restore the Kingdom to Israel (Acts 1:6). Moses disobeyed Jehovah by striking the rock and was not allowed to enter the Promised Land (Numbers 20:11-12). If these faithful servants made mistakes but Jehovah still used them, why be scandalized if some errors happened in the early days of this organization?

ğŸ”¹ 3. What matters is the fruit and the humility to correct mistakes:
Jesus taught: â€œBy their fruits you will recognize themâ€ (Matthew 7:16). And what fruits has this organization produced? A peaceful people, morally clean, united in over 240 countries, preaching the Kingdom of God and helping millions change their lives. Also, when a mistake in understanding or practice is made, it is humbly corrected. That is a sign of spiritual maturity, not permanent guilt (Proverbs 4:18).

ğŸ”¹ 4. God uses whoever He wants, not those the world expects:
Jehovah has used shepherds, fishermen, tax collectors, and builders to fulfill His will. What matters is the message, not the messenger. As Paul said: â€œWe have this treasure in earthen vessels, so that the extraordinary power may be from God and not from usâ€ (2 Corinthians 4:7).

ğŸ”¹ 5. And youâ€”who do you follow?
Many who criticize Jehovahâ€™s Witnesses because of Russell follow religious leaders who also made mistakes. But we do not judge them for that. Instead, we encourage everyone to focus on the Bible, not on men.

âœ… Conclusion:
I am not one of Jehovahâ€™s Witnesses because of Russell. I am because, by studying the Bible with prayer and humility, I have found a people striving to do Jehovahâ€™s will. Are they perfect? No. Are they willing to learn, correct themselves, and move forward? Yes! And that is what Jehovah expects of his servants (Micah 6:8).
